headline: Kano govt to review teachers’ retirement age
summarized_story:
Kano State Executive Council has approved plans for review and harmonisation of retirement age for teachers effective January 2022 with a committee to draft the documents for actualisation of the exercise.
This is contained in a statement signed by the State Commissioner for Information, Mr Muhammed Garba, and made available on Sunday.
The statement explained that the exercise would require an increase in salaries and other emoluments of teachers not provided for in the 2021 budget.
According to him, the committee will also review the scheme and condition of service of teachers to accommodate the new retirement age.
With the new proposal, teachers’ retirement age will increase from 35 service years and 60 years of age to 40 years of service and 65 years of age respectively.

However, she urged all candidates, supporters, and electorate to ensure they observed COVID-19 safety protocols at polling units at the elections.

headline: Emir of Jama’are, Muhammadu Wabi is dead

Yusuf-Jarma said that Wabi died at the age of 92, at about 12:15 a.m. on Sunday morning at Aminu Kano Teaching Hospital after a ‘protracted illness.’Wabi was installed emir in 1970 following the death of his father Muhammadu Wabi II.
The late emir is survived by four wives, 35 children and many grandchildren.

headline: Rising global interest rates signal costly debt for Nigeria
summarized_story:
Nigeria in its proposed budget intends to borrow N2.57 trillion from international sources but the cost of the debt may be a major source of concern, considering that global interest rates are likely to rise.
For instance, the Bank of England last Thursday imposed back-to-back interest rate hikes for the first time since 2004, and began the process of quantitative tightening.
Four members voted to increase rates by 50 basis points to 0.75% percent.
The rise in global interest rates, which may however elude the Eurozone, means Nigeria with debt service to revenue ratio of 70 percent last year would have to pay more on borrowing.
“If global rates are rising then we must brace for higher debt service costs,” said Bismarck Rewane, an economist and CEO of Financial Derivatives Company (FDC).

headline: New payment system to allow naira across Africa
summarized_story:
Nigerians can now use naira to buy goods and services from other African countries without the hurdle of converting to the dollar, thanks to the new African payment system – Pan-African Payment and Settlement System (PAPSS).
The new African payment system was officially launched on January 13, 2022, in Accra, Ghana.
According to Afreximbank, PAPSS provides the solution to the disconnected and fragmented nature of payment and settlement systems that have long impeded intra-African trade.
Prior to the introduction of the new African payment system, over 80 percent of African cross-border payment transactions originating from African banks had to be routed offshore for clearing and settlement using international banking relationships.
That posed multiple challenges, ranging from payment delays to operational inefficiencies and compliance concerns for the disparate regional payment systems.

headline: Nigeria: At Amaechi’s Turbaning, Daura Emir Says Emirate Doesn’t Give Chieftaincy Titles for Money
summarized_story:
Speaking while conferring the chieftaincy title of Dan Amanar Daura (the Trusted Son of Daura) on the Minister of Transportation, Mr Chibuike Rotimi Amaechi in the ancient city of Daura, the emir said he had no regret conferring the chieftaincy title on the minister.
“Nigerians should not insinuate that the emirate is looking for money or has no money.
I want to announce to all Nigerians and everybody here that this emirate doesn’t give chieftaincy titles because of money or any position.
“I had never given chieftaincy titles because of money, fear of somebody or position.
We give chieftaincy titles based on merit and to help our masses who God will ask us hereafter,” the monarch explained.
